thread.title: Brad Rock: With the Utes, it's always going to tie to Wilson
thread.title_full: Brad Rock: With the Utes, it's always going to tie to Wilson | Deseret News

author: Brad Rock
title: Brad Rock: With the Utes, it's always going to tie to Wilson
text:
Utah quarterback Travis Wilson doesn't dominate but does what he needs in win over Arizona State.
Upcoming Games Utah Football Utah Utah @ USC Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum, Los Angeles Oct. 24, 5:30 p.m. 5 Days 23 Hrs 27 Mins 58 Secs More Coverage Utah's usual trength —special teams — is Utes' weakness in victory over ASU Utes report card vs. Arizona State Utes remain unbeaten with 34-18 win over Arizona State Utes go to the air with Wilson on rainy night With Hillary Clinton, the email issue keeps coming up. With the Kardashians, it’s one drama after another. And with the Utes , the Travis Wilson story just keeps giving.
It’s a recurring theme. Wilson made Oregon look like Keystone Cops. But he followed that up with a modest two-interception night against Cal. Saturday in a 34-18 win over Arizona State, he was better.
His rushing game is always a bonus on a team that already has Devontae Booker. But his passing? His short throws, most of the time, are fine, but his downfield game can be off-and-on.
Saturday it was not bad.
“We are not really potent on offense unless we’re throwing the ball well,” coach Kyle Whittingham said a few days before meeting Arizona State. “It’s all great to have a tailback like Devontae and be able to run the rock like we have, but you have to be able to throw to be a complete offense. Look back at last year’s game (at ASU). I still feel the same way. We should have thrown the ball more in that game.”
They worked on it against ASU.
The game’s first touchdown looked painfully easy. Wilson completed passes of 16, 21 and 21 yards before finishing off with a play-action pass to Harrison Handley.
For most of the night, Wilson looked as advertised: a seasoned senior whose job is to manage games, not dominate them. He made some nice throws, but also overthrew receivers a few deep routes. Early in the game, he was making his mid-range passes but missing on the long stuff.
And then he was suddenly the monster that devoured Oregon, connecting on a 42-yard streak to Kenneth Scott and following with the 11-yard scoring pass. He threw a 29-yard completion up the middle to Ken Hampel and a 22-yard completion to Tyrone Smith on third-and-12.
The Utes weren’t killing it, but Wilson was in the groove and on the move.
At the half, he was 18-24 for 220 yards passing.
The closeness of the game certainly wasn’t Wilson’s fault. Nor was it the defense’s. ASU had only 91 yards in the first half. But poor special teams coverage kept the Sun Devils close.
Wilson’s confidence was obvious. He found Kenneth Scott for 35 yards in the third quarter and finished with 297 passing yards on 26-36 passing.
Not huge numbers.
Wilson numbers.
That’s the never-ending story.
It’s not all on Wilson.
But of course it will be, all season.
But it wasn’t a pass but a pitch that might have been his best play. Wilson waited until just the right moment early in the fourth quarter to pitch to Booker for a 25-yard scoring play with 10:41 remaining, giving Utah a 21-18 lead. Booker didn’t stop until he hit traffic at Point of the Mountain.
Wilson followed by moving them into field goal range twice more, which Andy Phillips converted.
Uneven as Wilson has been in his career — he once threw six picks in a game — he’s better than his predecessor, Jordan Wynn. With the latter, it was a gamble if he’d even be upright on game day. Wilson has been remarkably durable, willing to play through the stuff that happens.
How good would the Utes be if he were more dominating? Against Oregon he was fast with his reads and delivery, perfect in his audibles, decisive with his execution. He was iffy against Cal, seldom moving the team via the pass. Even so, he went into that game with the No. 1 Total Quarterback Rating in the country. This week he was rated No. 7 on the ESPN metric.
He was good enough on Saturday, which is the way he’ll probably be all year.
Wilson maintains a temperament that protects him from critics. He fields questions without getting defensive, but without revealing anything, either. He doesn’t deny responsibility, but doesn’t put it all on himself.
If the Utes are going to take this season some place important, he’ll need to stay Good Travis, not Flaky Travis. On Saturday, he was Good Enough Travis. He’ll never be All-American, but he could end up with a reality show. Either that or making a run for president.
Email: rock@desnews.com ; Twitter: @therockmonster; Blog: Rockmonster Unplugged
